With 51 labs i'm working on a new contract, this was my last proposal that won me the contract: Proposal for Climate Consultant Expert Services 

Bilal Ghalib 

January 17, 2025 

1\. Project Understanding 

Five One Labs seeks to integrate climate resilience practices into its 32-session Incubator Program curriculum. This initiative aims to equip entrepreneurs in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq (KRI) with the tools to address local environmental challenges while aligning with global sustainability goals. 

2\. Technical Approach & Methodology 

Key Steps 

1\. Curriculum Review 

‚Ä¢ Analyze all 32 sessions to identify opportunities for integrating climate re silience concepts. 

‚Ä¢ Draft a session-by-session outline with proposed climate-related enhancements. 2\. Content Development 

‚Ä¢ Create or adapt slides, trainer notes, and case studies in English, focusing on climate resilience and sustainability. 

‚Ä¢ Initial translation of materials into Arabic and Kurdish. 

3\. Finalization & Handover 

‚Ä¢ Refine translation and materials based on feedback from Five One Labs. 

‚Ä¢ Provide a Trainer Guide with talking points and references. 

‚Ä¢ Conduct a final handover session to ensure smooth adoption of the curriculum. 

3\. Work Plan & Timeline 

Duration: January 21 ‚Äì February 25, 2025 (5 weeks) 

| Step  | Deliverables  | Timeframe |
| ----- | ----- | ----- |
| 1\. Curriculum Review  | Climate Integration Outline, Feedback & Iteration  | Week 1‚Äì2 |
| 2\. Content Development  | Climate-Integrated Curriculum & Draft Translations  | Week 3‚Äì4 |
| 3\. Finalization & Handover  | Complete Curriculum Package \+ Handover Session  | Week 5 |

1  
4\. Financial Bid 

Total Lump Sum: 4,000,000 IQD (Inclusive of all project expenses, translation, and taxes) 

| Step  | Rate (IQD) |
| ----- | ----- |
| Curriculum Review  | 1,200,000 |
| Content Development  | 2,000,000 |
| Translation, Finalization & Handover  | 800,000 |
| Total  | 4,000,000 |

5\. Payment Terms 

‚Ä¢ Schedule: One-time payment upon completion of all deliverables, expected on or before February 25, 2025\. 

‚Ä¢ Method: Bank transfer. 

‚Ä¢ Currency: IQD (inclusive of taxes). 

6\. Closing Statement 

Thank you for considering this proposal. My objective is to provide a practical and impactful climate-focused curriculum that empowers entrepreneurs to create sustainable businesses in KRI. Please feel free to contact me for any questions or clarifications. 

Sincerely, 

Bilal Ghalib 

Educational Research Consultant 

bg@bilalghalib.com ‚Äî \+14782272253 

2Now they sent me a new TOR and i want to adapt my proposal for them: [[[**TERMS OF REFERENCE**   
**CURRICULUM ADAPTATION CONSULTANT** 

**‚óè BACKGROUND INFORMATION** 

Country: Iraq (Kurdistan Region)   
Project: Leveraging on Technology ‚Äì Making Every Bite Count 

Five One Labs, in collaboration with DCA, is integrating food waste and food security insights into its entrepreneurial bootcamp curriculum. This initiative aims to equip entrepreneurs with practical tools and case studies to design solutions to local food system challenges. 

The Curriculum Adaptation Consultant will use findings from the research phase to develop and adapt training content, ensuring that the bootcamp effectively addresses food waste reduction, redistribution models, and food security in Erbil‚Äôs cultural and economic context. 

**‚óè CONTRACT PURPOSE AND EXPECTED RESULTS** 

**Overall objective:**   
The overall objective of the project is to reduce food waste and improve food security in Erbil through evidence-based, community-driven redistribution models. 

**Purpose:**   
The purpose of this contract is to engage a Curriculum Adaptation Consultant to design and adapt entrepreneurial training content that integrates food waste and food security findings. The consultant will ensure the bootcamp curriculum provides practical tools, exercises, and case studies for participants to develop scalable solutions to food system challenges in Erbil, resulting in a finalized curriculum and facilitator guide ready for the next bootcamp cycle. 

**Results to be achieved by the Contractor:** 

1\. Updated curriculum and modules that incorporate research findings on food waste reduction, redistribution models, and food security into Five One Labs‚Äô 4-day bootcamp format. 

2\. Trainer and participant materials (slides, guides, and workbooks) that are practical, localized, and ready for immediate use in training sessions. 

3\. Impact framework with clear indicators to measure outcomes such as food saved, households reached, and business results from participating entrepreneurs. 

4\. Training-of-trainers session to build the capacity of Five One Labs staff and facilitators to deliver the updated curriculum effectively and consistently. 

**‚óè SCOPE OF THE SERVICES** 

**Project Information**   
Five One Labs, in collaboration with DCA, is integrating food waste and food security insights into its entrepreneurial bootcamp curriculum in Erbil, Iraq. This initiative equips entrepreneurs with practical tools to design scalable, community-driven solutions to food system challenges, including food waste reduction, redistribution models, and improved food access. 

**Tasks to be Carried Out by the Contractor** 

‚óè Review findings from the three research phase reports and extract actionable insights. ‚óè Review Five One Labs‚Äô 4-day bootcamp curriculum and integrate relevant findings. 

Procurement Manual 6ED 1 / 2![][image1]  
‚óè Develop updated training modules, exercises, and tools linking entrepreneurship to food waste/security. 

‚óè Provide localized and global case studies of food-waste-related ventures.   
‚óè Adapt standard entrepreneurship tools (e.g., Business Model Canvas, prototyping, pitching) to this context. 

‚óè Design an impact framework to measure outcomes (e.g., food saved, households reached, business outcomes). 

‚óè Deliver updated trainer and participant materials (slides, guides, workbooks).   
‚óè Conduct a training-of-trainers session with the Five One Labs team. 

**Management Structure**   
The contractor will report to Five One Labs‚Äô Programs Team, with oversight from the Managing Director responsible for the DCA project. Regular check-ins will be scheduled to review progress and provide feedback. 

**‚óè TIMING, LOGISITICS AND FACILITIES** 

**Timing** The contract will run for 6 weeks from the date of signing. 

**Location**   
The work can be completed remotely, with at least one virtual session scheduled with the Five One Labs team in Erbil for curriculum co-design and validation. 

**Facilities Provided by the Contracting Authority** 

‚ùñ Access to existing curriculum materials and research reports.   
‚ùñ Coordination and scheduling support for team check-ins and the training-of-trainers session. **Facilities Provided by the Contractor** 

‚ùñ Independent work environment and necessary software/tools to complete deliverables. ‚ùñ Preparation of all materials in digital format (editable). 

**‚óè REPORTING** 

Deliverables will be submitted electronically to the Managing Director at Five One Labs. Interim check-ins (weekly or bi-weekly) will be held to review progress. 

Final deliverables will include: updated curriculum, training materials, impact framework, and training-of-trainers session plan. 

All documents must be submitted in English. 

**‚óè QUALIFICATION REQUIREMENTS** 

‚ùñ Proven experience in entrepreneurship training and curriculum design.   
‚ùñ Familiarity with food systems, food waste, and/or food security.   
‚ùñ Ability to contextualize global entrepreneurship tools for local use.   
‚ùñ Strong communication skills and ability to deliver materials in clear, engaging formats. ‚ùñ Fluent in English, Kurdish, and Arabic (preferred). 

Procurement Manual 6ED ]]]

First give me your analysis about my position based on everything you know about me in our ocntext history and how i can pitch myself and then can you ask me 5 questions to help you get the context in order to send them a new proposal?

Got it ‚Äî let‚Äôs zoom out first.  

### üìå Analysis of Your Position  
Based on your history and the TOR:  

1. **Credibility** ‚Äì You already delivered successfully on a *similar contract with 51 Labs* (climate resilience integration). That gives you leverage: you‚Äôre a *trusted provider* who knows their workflows, curriculum style, and expectations. You‚Äôre not coming in cold.  

2. **Strengths**  
   - Deep **curriculum design** and **entrepreneurship training** background (Bloom, 400+ entrepreneurs, 350+ mentors trained).  
   - **Experience contextualizing** global tools (BMC, prototyping, pitching) to fragile / crisis-affected settings (Lebanon, Iraq, Palestine).  
   - **Systems perspective** (food, climate, economics) ‚Äî you don‚Äôt just add slides, you build frameworks and impact indicators.  
   - **Creative, practical methodology** ‚Äî you emphasize not replacing existing systems but weaving in resilience, belonging, and community agency. This maps well to *food redistribution models and community-driven solutions*.  

3. **Positioning Angle**  
   - You‚Äôre not ‚Äújust‚Äù an adapter. You‚Äôre a **bridge**: between research ‚Üí curriculum ‚Üí trainer capacity ‚Üí measurable community impact.  
   - Your edge is in **local sensitivity + global frameworks**. You can bring in case studies from MENA (e.g. informal food markets, Lebanon community fridges) alongside international best practice.  
   - You can frame yourself as someone who **helps entrepreneurs see food waste not only as a problem but as a business opportunity**, connecting social impact to viable ventures.  

4. **Risks to Address**  
   - They‚Äôre asking for *food waste/food security familiarity*. You haven‚Äôt branded yourself as a ‚Äúfood systems expert‚Äù before ‚Äî but you *can frame* your climate/sustainability work as adjacent. And your experience with value chains, social enterprises, and resilience easily transfers.  
   - They want ‚Äúimpact framework with indicators.‚Äù You should emphasize your past **research (Beirut Blast thesis, PTG data analysis)** and how you can design practical measurement tools (food saved, households reached, etc.).  

5. **Tone for Pitch**  
   - Practical, evidence-based, but also creative.  
   - ‚ÄúI‚Äôve already done this with your climate curriculum. Now I can apply the same tested process to food waste/security.‚Äù  
   - Stress co-creation, humility, and adaptability: ‚Äúnot just importing models, but working with your team to localize them.‚Äù  

---

### üìå Five Questions for You  
Before drafting your adapted proposal, I need clarity on these:  

1. **Case Studies** ‚Äì Do you already have in mind local or regional food waste/food security examples you‚Äôd like to highlight (e.g. Lebanon, Iraq, MENA region), or should I source and contextualize global ones?  

2. **Impact Framework** ‚Äì How sophisticated should the measurement be? (simple indicators like *kg of food saved per entrepreneur* vs. more complex ones like *household nutrition outcomes, revenue changes*).  

3. **Trainer Capacity-Building** ‚Äì Do you want to propose just one ToT session (as TOR requires), or do you want to add optional follow-up mentoring/coaching of trainers?  

4. **Translation & Language** ‚Äì In your last proposal, you budgeted for Kurdish/Arabic translation. Do you want to include that here again, or should we keep materials in English and leave translation to them?  

5. **Budget & Positioning** ‚Äì Last time you proposed 4M IQD (~$3K). Do you want to stay in that ballpark, increase (since scope is bigger: impact framework + ToT), or price more competitively to secure repeat work?  

---

üëâ Want me to then draft you a **proposal skeleton** (same structure as your winning climate one, adapted to this TOR) so you can plug in details once you answer these 5?

This is one of the things I love to talk about because my grandma would tell me about making cold, cured sausages in dry heat, hanging them making so many things from the dates in their backyards from baskets to vinegar to date, molasses and date paste and cookies, and how seasonally connected things are and I feel like maybe there could be a really beautiful elements of knowledge preservation from our ancestors are like our grandmothers before it goes away, especially in terms of food preservation, and Iraqi are also really known to love their giant fridges, and it would be lovely to study the history of the fridge. You know I know that we used to have ice chest boxes and how did that work and what did they do when there was no more ice and that would be a beautiful thing as I'm not sure about translation because they didn't actually talk about it. Do they talk about it at all I would love to propose at least one TOT session, but tell them that follow up and connections would be more than welcome and I'm more than willing to come to Iraq if the budget allows yeah is the scope bigger there is the material production impact framework in TOT I think yeah maybe 4K. Can you help me think about you know making actually a table and what the budget might be for each of the things that's reasonable they can hire local so it would need to be reasonable for them to hire me from France to come just helpful. Do you need anything else and yeah, I'd like to have an updated proposal.

Love this direction, Bilal. You‚Äôve got a very natural bridge from your climate-curriculum win to a food-systems bootcamp: research ‚Üí localization ‚Üí trainer capacity ‚Üí measurable impact. Below I: (1) give you a quick research primer you can cite, (2) propose indicators and a lean impact framework, (3) give you a 6-week workplan + budget table around ~$4k, and (4) drop in a ready-to-send proposal draft you can tweak.

# Fast research primer (for your case-study pack)
- **Erbil/KRI context:** Local org estimates ~**600 tons/day** of edible food discarded in Erbil (‚âà31.5% of municipal waste). Regionally, up to **~50%** of refuse is food. ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search7ÓàÅ  
- **Iraq & UN bodies:** UN Iraq notes **13%** global supply-chain loss + **17%** wasted at consumer level; loss/waste drives hunger & methane emissions. ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search6ÓàÅ  
- **FAO/WFP framing:** Food loss/waste contributes **6‚Äì8%** of global GHGs; methane is ~**80x** CO‚ÇÇ warming power short-term‚Äîuseful climate co-benefit angle. ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search0ÓàÅ  
- **Regional exemplars to localize:**
  - **Lebanon community fridges** scaling from 1 to a citywide network‚Äîgrassroots redistribution model. ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search2ÓàÅ
  - **UAE Food Bank** + partners saved **millions of meals**; strong ops model & partnerships (hotels, restaurants, events). ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search3ÓàÇturn0search21ÓàÅ
  - **Egyptian Food Bank** repurposes surplus from hospitality + jobs pathways; long-running MENA case. ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search10ÓàÇturn0search16ÓàÅ  
- **Cultural preservation module (optional):** Traditional Iraqi **date preservation** (dibs / date syrup), regionally documented (Mesopotamian roots; madabis presses). Great for ‚Äúheritage know-how ‚Üí modern ventures.‚Äù ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search5ÓàÇturn0search11ÓàÇturn0search17ÓàÅ

# Impact framework (lean, early-stage friendly)
**Core bootcamp indicators (simple & practical):**
- **Food saved (kg)** per venture during pilot period.  
- **Redistribution reach:** # of **households** or **meals** reached.  
- **Sourcing partners onboarded:** restaurants, groceries, farms.  
- **Business traction:** monthly revenue (USD/IQD), unit economics per kg saved.  
- **Waste diversion rate (%)** from partner sites (pre/post spot checks).  

**Optional ‚Äúwider lens‚Äù metrics (add if team wants broader scope):**
- **Avg. distance traveled** for redistributed food (km) to explore ‚Äúlocal loops.‚Äù  
- **Storage/preservation wins:** # of SKUs with extended shelf life using **traditional methods** (pickling, drying, fermenting, date by-products).  
- **Education/behavior:** # staff trained; # customer engagements; plate-waste reductions from pilots (if any).  
These keep it measurable without over-engineering for an early phase.

# 6-week plan (matches TOR) + budget (~$4k target)
**Timeline (remote + 1 virtual co-design; optional in-person if budget allows):**
- **Week 1‚Äì2:** Synthesize 3 research reports; shortlist localizable case studies; gap map vs. existing 4-day bootcamp; co-design call.  
- **Week 3‚Äì4:** Adapt modules (BMC for redistribution, sourcing ops, prototyping, pitching); build exercises & tools; draft slides, trainer notes, participant workbook.  
- **Week 5:** Build **impact mini-kit** (tracker sheets, definitions, data-collection scripts); refine materials.  
- **Week 6:** **ToT session** (2‚Äì3h) + revisions; final handover.

**Budget (IQD & USD rough-equivalent):**

| Work package | Scope highlight | IQD | USD approx. |
|---|---|---:|---:|
| Research synthesis & case-study pack | Read 3 reports; extract insights; 6‚Äì8 localized cases | 1,300,000 | 1,000 |
| Curriculum integration (4-day) | Adapt agendas, exercises, tools; facilitator flow | 1,560,000 | 1,200 |
| Materials production | Slides, trainer notes, participant workbook (editable) | 910,000 | 700 |
| Impact framework mini-kit | Indicators, data sheets, simple dashboard templates | 650,000 | 500 |
| ToT (virtual, 2‚Äì3h) + revisions | Run session; collect feedback; finalize | 650,000 | 500 |
| **Total (base)** |  | **5,070,000** | **~3,900‚Äì4,000** |

**Optional add-ons (price separately):**
- **Follow-up coaching of trainers** (3x 60-min clinics over 6‚Äì8 weeks): **520,000 IQD (~$400)**.  
- **Translation (AR/KU) coordination**: treat as pass-through or handled by FOL; I can QA glossary if desired.  
- **In-person delivery (Erbil)**: travel days + expenses at cost; day rate **650,000 IQD (~$500)**.

> Notes: Kept total near your ~$4k target while reflecting added scope (impact kit + ToT). Translation wasn‚Äôt requested in TOR; I‚Äôd keep it optional.

# Updated proposal (ready to send)
**Proposal for Curriculum Adaptation Consultant ‚Äî Food Waste & Food Security Bootcamp**  
**Bilal Ghalib** ‚Äî October 7, 2025

## 1. Project Understanding  
Five One Labs, with DCA, is integrating **food waste reduction, redistribution models, and food security** into its **4-day entrepreneurial bootcamp** in Erbil. The goal is to translate recent research into practical tools, exercises, and ventures that reduce food waste, expand access, and create viable social businesses in KRI.

## 2. Technical Approach & Methodology  
**Key Steps**  
1) **Research Synthesis & Localization**  
- Review the three research reports; extract **actionable insights** for venture design.  
- Curate a **case-study pack** (local/regional/global) on redistribution models, community fridges, hospitality surplus, and preservation-based micro-ventures. ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search7ÓàÇturn0search2ÓàÇturn0search3ÓàÇturn0search21ÓàÇturn0search10ÓàÅ  

2) **Curriculum Adaptation (4-day format)**  
- Integrate findings into the bootcamp flow (ideation ‚Üí validation ‚Üí prototyping ‚Üí pitching).  
- Adapt **BMC** for redistribution logistics, sourcing agreements, cold-chain alternatives, preservation methods, and unit economics.  
- Build **hands-on tools**: supplier mapping, surplus audit, ‚Äúmeals equivalent‚Äù calculator, partner outreach scripts.

3) **Materials Development**  
- **Trainer**: slides, facilitation guide, timed agendas, FAQs.  
- **Participants**: workbook with canvases, trackers, and prototyping prompts.  
- All files **editable** (Google/MS formats) for easy reuse.

4) **Impact Framework (Lean, Bootcamp-ready)**  
- Indicators: **kg of food saved**, **households/meals reached**, **partners onboarded**, **basic unit economics**; optional add-ons include **distance traveled** and **preservation wins**.  
- Provide a **mini-kit**: definitions, data sheets, and a simple aggregator template.

5) **Training-of-Trainers (ToT)**  
- 2‚Äì3h virtual session for FOL staff/facilitators: walkthrough, practice, and Q&A.  
- Optional: **3 follow-up clinics** to support first delivery.

## 3. Work Plan & Timeline (6 weeks)  
| Step | Deliverables | Timeframe |
|---|---|---|
| Research Synthesis & Case Studies | Insight brief + 6‚Äì8 localizable cases | Weeks 1‚Äì2 |
| Curriculum Integration | Updated 4-day agendas, exercises, tools | Weeks 3‚Äì4 |
| Materials & Impact Kit | Slides, guides, participant workbook, indicators | Week 5 |
| ToT & Finalization | ToT session + revisions; final handover | Week 6 |

## 4. Financial Bid (Lump Sum, editable files included)  
**Total (base): 5,070,000 IQD (~$3,900‚Äì4,000).**  
Breakdown: Research 1,300,000; Curriculum 1,560,000; Materials 910,000; Impact Kit 650,000; ToT & revisions 650,000.

**Optional Add-ons**  
- Trainer coaching (3x clinics): **520,000 IQD (~$400)**.  
- Translation (AR/KU) coordination: **TBD** / pass-through.  
- In-person delivery (Erbil): **day rate 650,000 IQD (~$500)** + travel at cost.

## 5. Management & Reporting  
- Report to Five One Labs Programs Team with oversight from Managing Director (DCA project).  
- **Weekly check-ins** (or biweekly) for rapid iteration.  
- Final package: updated curriculum, trainer & participant materials, **impact framework**, and ToT plan.  
- **All documents in English;** translation optional per FOL preference.

## 6. Closing  
I previously delivered a successful climate-integration contract with Five One Labs; I‚Äôll apply the same practical, co-creative approach here‚Äîturning research into **immediately usable** training and measurable outcomes. I‚Äôm happy to add heritage preservation elements (fermentation, drying, date-based products) as inspirational venture pathways aligned with Erbil‚Äôs context. ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search5ÓàÇturn0search11ÓàÇturn0search17ÓàÅ

**Bilal Ghalib**  
Educational Research & Curriculum Design  
bg@bilalghalib.com ‚Ä¢ +1-478-227-2253

---

If you want, I can tailor the case-study pack to your friends‚Äô initiatives (women-led home production, regional agri ventures). Also: want me to add a one-page **heritage preservation** module outline (quick wins + venture ideas) to include in the annex?

I'll search for food waste and food systems research reports that would be relevant for this project. Let me look for recent, authoritative sources that focus on the Middle East/Iraq context or have applicable frameworks.Perfect! I found some strong research. Now let me organize this for you and help you think through the budget and positioning.

## 6 Research Reports for Your Review:

**1. UNEP Food Waste Index Report 2024** ‚≠ê **MUST HAVE**
- Global food waste measurement methodology + SDG 12.3 tracking
- Includes Middle East data, measurement frameworks, and impact indicators
- Provides the "official" language and metrics you'll need
- [Access here](https://www.unep.org/resources/publication/food-waste-index-report-2024)

**2. Food waste in Iraqi restaurants (Filimonau et al., 2023)** ‚≠ê **HIGHLY RELEVANT**
- **Actual Iraq-specific data**: 38g per capita food waste in Iraqi restaurants
- Cultural factors: hospitality culture, large portions, over-ordering
- Novel/effective approaches for Middle East market
- This is gold for understanding Erbil context

**3. FAO Food Loss and Waste in Arab World (systematic review, 2018)**
- **Critical stat**: 210 kg per capita annually in Arab countries vs 95-115kg in Europe
- Data gaps in 10 Arab countries including Iraq
- Food bank initiatives and redistribution models in the region
- Shows the opportunity space

**4. Traditional Iraqi Fermented Foods (Journal of Ethnic Foods, 2022)** ‚≠ê **YOUR SECRET WEAPON**
- Documents Iraq's 7500 BC food preservation tradition
- Basturma, Turshi, date products, fermentation techniques
- **Low commercialization** = entrepreneurship opportunity!
- Connects to your grandmother's knowledge angle

**5. Circular Economy & Food Waste (ReFED + UNCTAD reports)**
- Entrepreneurship frameworks for food waste
- Business Model Canvas adaptations for circular economy
- Case studies of food waste social enterprises
- Impact measurement approaches

**6. NRC Iraq Drought & Food Security Report (Nov 2024)** ‚≠ê **CURRENT CONTEXT**
- 1 in 2 Iraqi households cultivated less land in 2024
- 59% reduced food expenditure
- Climate-food security-income nexus
- Shows urgency and context for the work

## Your Honest Positioning - How to Frame It:

**DON'T say**: "I'm a food systems expert"

**DO say**: "I specialize in curriculum adaptation for complex topics I don't initially know deeply - I've done this successfully with solar energy, insulation, and green architecture for ITC. My strength is synthesis: taking research findings and translating them into practical entrepreneurship tools that work in SWANA contexts."

**Your Unique Angle** (this is actually brilliant):
"I want to integrate traditional Iraqi food preservation knowledge - which dates back 7500 years but risks being lost - with modern circular economy approaches. Entrepreneurs in Erbil don't just need Western frameworks; they need to see how their grandmothers' techniques (fermentation, sun-drying, date preservation) are actually cutting-edge circular economy practices."

This positions your "gap" as a **feature, not a bug**. You're not pretending to be a food scientist - you're positioning as someone who connects indigenous knowledge with modern entrepreneurship frameworks.

## Budget Strategy & Breakdown:

**Context check:**
- Climate project: 4M IQD for 5 weeks, single deliverable stream
- This project: 6 weeks, MORE complex (research synthesis + curriculum + materials + impact framework + ToT)
- Question: In-person or remote?

**My recommendation:** 
Price at **4.5M - 5M IQD** (~$3,400-$3,800 USD) for remote work. If they want in-person facilitation in Erbil, add 1.3M IQD ($1,000) = **5.8M-6.3M IQD total**.

Here's a transparent breakdown:

| **Deliverable** | **Remote (IQD)** | **Notes** |
|---|---|---|
| **Research Synthesis & Integration** | 1,200,000 | Review 3 research reports + 6 background sources, extract actionable insights, create integration outline |
| **Curriculum Adaptation (4-day bootcamp)** | 1,800,000 | Adapt Five One Labs bootcamp format, integrate food waste/security content, develop exercises linking to entrepreneurship tools |
| **Training Materials Development** | 1,000,000 | Slides, trainer guides, participant workbooks, case studies (localized + global) |
| **Impact Framework Design** | 700,000 | Develop measurement system: kg saved, households reached, business outcomes, data collection tools |
| **Training-of-Trainers Session** | 800,000 | Virtual ToT session + prep materials |
| **TOTAL (Remote)** | **5,500,000** | ~$4,200 USD |

| **If In-Person Required** | **Additional** |
|---|---|
| Travel to Erbil + accommodation | +1,300,000 | ~$1,000 USD |
| **TOTAL (In-Person)** | **6,800,000** | ~$5,200 USD |

**Reality Check**: Are they likely to hire someone from France?
- **Yes, if**: You emphasize your Five One Labs track record, Kurdistan Region familiarity, Arabic fluency, and recent successful delivery
- **No, if**: They have budget constraints and strong local options

**My advice**: **Propose remote-first with optional in-person**. Say: "I can deliver all work remotely with excellent results, as demonstrated in my climate curriculum project. However, if budget allows, an in-person ToT session in Erbil would strengthen trainer capacity and allow for real-time troubleshooting."

## Key Questions Before I Draft:

1. **Do you want to actually pitch the traditional knowledge integration angle?** It's risky (could seem unfocused) but also potentially differentiating.

2. **Translation**: The TOR doesn't mention it. Your climate project did. Should we include basic Arabic/Kurdish glossaries or skip it?

3. **Timeline**: They say 6 weeks. Can you do end of October through early December? Or do you need different dates?

4. **The research reports they mention**: Do you want me to email them asking for access to the three research phase reports, or wait until they provide them?

5. **Your friend in agriculture/food work**: Is this someone you could list as a "technical advisor" to strengthen your food systems credibility?

What do you think about this framing? Should I draft the proposal now, or do you want to adjust the positioning/budget first?

This is a really sharp synthesis. Here‚Äôs how I see it, Bilal:  

---

### üß≠ Positioning You
- You don‚Äôt need to posture as a ‚Äúfood systems expert.‚Äù Your edge is **curriculum adaptation in new technical domains** (you‚Äôve done this with climate, solar, green building).  
- Your strength is **translation**: turning complex reports into *practical entrepreneurship exercises* that work in SWANA contexts.  
- Adding **traditional Iraqi preservation knowledge** is a brilliant differentiator. It reframes ‚Äúgap in food expertise‚Äù as **bridge between heritage and modern circular economy**. It‚Äôs *uniquely you*.  

---

### üí∞ Budget Framing

It is meant to act as a field guide to help detect undisclosed AI-generated content on Wikipedia. This list is descriptive, not prescriptive; it consists of observations, not rules. Advice about formatting or language to avoid in Wikipedia articles can be found in the policies and guidelines and the Manual of Style, but does not belong on this page.

This list is not a ban on certain words, phrases, or punctuation. No one is taking your em-dashes away or claiming that only LLMs use them. Not all text featuring the following indicators is AI-generated, as the large language models that power AI chatbots are trained on human writing, including the writing of Wikipedia editors. This is simply a catalog of very common patterns observed over many thousands of instances of AI-generated text, specific to Wikipedia. While some of its advice may be broadly applicable, some signs‚Äîparticularly those involving punctuation and formatting‚Äîmay not apply in a non-Wikipedia context.

The patterns here are also only potential signs of a problem, not the problem itself. While many of these issues are immediately obvious and easy to fix‚Äîe.g., excessive boldface, poor wordsmithing, broken markup, citation style quirks‚Äîthey can point to less outwardly visible problems that carry much more serious policy risks. If LLM-generated text is polished enough (initially or subsequently tidied up), those surface defects might not be present, but the deeper problems likely will. Please do not merely treat these signs as the problems to be fixed; that could just make detection harder. The actual problems are those deeper concerns, so make sure to address them, either yourself or by flagging them, per the advice at Wikipedia:Large language models ¬ß Handling suspected LLM-generated content and Wikipedia:WikiProject AI Cleanup/Guide.

The speedy deletion policy criterion G15 (LLM-generated pages without human review) is limited to the most objective and least contestable indications that the page's content was generated by an LLM. There are three such indicators, the first of which can be found in ¬ß Communication intended for the user and the other two in ¬ß Citations. The other signs, though they may indeed indicate AI use, are not sufficient for speedy deletion.

Do not solely rely on artificial intelligence content detection tools (such as GPTZero) to evaluate whether text is LLM-generated. While they perform better than random chance, these tools have nontrivial error rates and cannot replace human judgment.[1]

Language and tone
Shortcuts
WP:AIWTW
WP:AI-ISM
LLMs (and artificial neural networks in general) use statistical algorithms to guess (infer) what should come next based on a large corpus of training material. It thus tends to regress to the mean; that is, the result tends toward the most statistically likely result that applies to the widest variety of cases. It can simultaneously be a strength and a "tell" for detecting AI-generated content.

For example, LLMs are usually trained on data from the internet in which famous people are generally described with positive, important-sounding language. It will thus sand down specific, unusual, nuanced facts (which are statistically rare) and replace them with more generic, positive descriptions (which are statistically common). Thus the specific detail "invented a train-coupling device" might become "a revolutionary titan of industry." LLMs tend to smooth out unusual details and drift toward the most common, statistically probable way of describing a topic. It is like shouting louder and louder that a portrait shows a uniquely important person, while the portrait itself is fading from a sharp photograph into a blurry, generic sketch. The subject becomes simultaneously less specific and more exaggerated.[2]

This statistical regression to the mean, a smoothing over of specific facts into generic statements that could apply to many topics, makes AI-generated content easier to detect.

Undue emphasis on symbolism and importance
Words to watch: stands as / serves as / is a testament, plays a vital/significant/crucial role, underscores its importance, highlights its significance, continues to captivate, leaves a lasting impact, watershed moment, key turning point, deeply rooted, profound heritage, steadfast dedication, indelible mark, solidifies ...
LLM writing often puffs up the importance of the subject matter with reminders that it represents or contributes to a broader topic.[3] There seems to be only a small repertoire of ways that it writes these reminders, so if they are otherwise appropriate it would be best to reword them anyway.

When talking about biology (e.g. when asked to discuss a given animal or plant species), LLMs tend to put too much emphasis on the species' conservation status and the efforts to protect it, even if the status is unknown and no serious efforts exist.

Generative AI has a repetition-penalty code, meant to discourage it from reusing words too often.[3] For instance, the output might give a main character's name and then repeatedly use a different synonym or related term (e.g., protagonist, key player, eponymous character) when mentioning it again.

False ranges
Shortcuts
WP:FROMXTOY
WP:FALSERANGE
When from ... to ... constructions are not used figuratively, they are used to indicate the lower and upper bounds of a scale. The scale is either quantitative, involving an explicit or implicit numerical range (e.g. from 1990 to 2000, from 15 to 20 ounces, from winter to autumn), or qualitative, involving categorical bounds (e.g. "from seed to tree", "from mild to severe", "from white belt to black belt"). The same constructions may be used to form a merism‚Äîa figure of speech that combines the two extremes as two contrasting parts of the whole to refer to the whole. This is a figurative meaning, but it has the same structure as the non-figurative usage, because it still requires an identifiable scale: from head to toe (the length of a body denoting the whole body), from soup to nuts (clearly based on time), etc. This is not a false range.

LLMs really like mixing it up, such as when giving examples of items within a set (instead of simply mentioning them one after another). An important consideration is whether some middle ground can be identified without changing the endpoints. If the middle requires switching from one scale to another scale, or there is no scale to begin with or a coherent whole that could be conceived, the construction is a false range. LLMs often employ "figurative" (often simply: meaningless) "from ... to ..." constructions that purport to signify a scale, while the endpoints are loosely related or essentially unrelated things and no meaningful scale can be inferred. LLMs do this because such meaningless language is used in persuasive writing to impress and woo, and LLMs are heavily influenced by materials consisting of persuasive writing during their training.

Examples

Our journey through the universe has taken us from the singularity of the Big Bang to the grand cosmic web, from the birth and death of stars that forge the elements of life, to the enigmatic dance of dark matter and dark energy that shape its destiny.

[...]

Intelligence and Creativity: From problem-solving and tool-making to scientific discovery, artistic expression, and technological innovation, human intelligence is characterized by its adaptability and capacity for novel solutions.

[...]

Continued Scientific Discovery: The quest to understand the universe, life, and ourselves will continue to drive scientific breakthroughs, from fundamental physics to medicine and neuroscience.

AI chatbots may display various phrases in boldface for emphasis in an excessive, mechanical manner. Some newer large language models or apps have instructions to avoid overuse of boldface.

Inline-header vertical lists
Shortcut
WP:AILIST
For non-AI-specific guidance about this, see Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Lists ¬ß Use prose where understood easily.
AI chatbots' content often includes vertical lists. A particular list formatting is employed: It comprises an ordered or unordered list where the list marker (number, bullet, dash, etc.) is followed by an inline boldfaced header of sorts; a colon then separates it from the remaining descriptive text. (Separately from this sign, this is one of the things which cause overabundant boldfacing; see ¬ß Excessive use of boldface)

Instead of proper wikitext, a bullet point in an unordered list may appear as a bullet character (‚Ä¢), hyphen (-), en dash (‚Äì), or similar character. Ordered lists (i.e. numbered lists) may use explicit numbers (such as 1.) instead of standard wikitext. When copied as bare text appearing on the screen, some of the formatting information is lost, and line breaks may be lost as well.

Curly quotation marks and apostrophes
For non-AI-specific guidance about this, see Wikipedia:Manual of Style ¬ß Quotation characters, and Wikipedia:Manual of Style ¬ß Apostrophes.
Shortcut
WP:AICURLY
AI chatbots typically use curly quotation marks (‚Äú...‚Äù or ‚Äò...‚Äô) instead of straight quotation marks ("..." or '...'). In some cases, AI chatbots inconsistently use pairs of curly and straight quotation marks in the same response. They also tend to use the curly apostrophe (‚Äô; the same character as the curly right single quotation mark) instead of the straight apostrophe ('), such as in contractions and possessive forms. They may also do this inconsistently.

Curly quotes alone do not prove LLM use. Microsoft Word as well as macOS and iOS devices have a "smart quotes" feature that converts straight quotes to curly quotes. Grammar correcting tools such as LanguageTool may also have such a feature. Curly quotation marks and apostrophes are common in professionally typeset works such as major newspapers. Citation tools like Citer may repeat those that appear in the title of a web page: for example,

McClelland, Mac (2017-09-27). "When 'Not Guilty' Is a Life Sentence". The New York Times. Retrieved 2025-08-03.

Note that Wikipedia allows users to customize the fonts used to display text. Some fonts display matched curly apostrophes as straight, in which case the distinction is invisible to the user.

Knowledge-cutoff disclaimers and speculation about gaps in sources
Shortcuts
WP:AICUTOFF
WP:AIDISCLAIMER
Words to watch: as of [date],[a] Up to my last training update, as of my last knowledge update, While specific details are limited/scarce..., not widely available/documented/disclosed, ...in the provided/available sources/search results..., based on available information ...
A knowledge-cutoff disclaimer is a statement used by the AI chatbot to indicate that the information provided may be incomplete, inaccurate, or outdated.

If an LLM has a fixed knowledge cutoff (usually the model's last training update), it is unable to provide any information on events or developments past that time, and it will often output a disclaimer to remind the user of this cutoff, which usually takes the form of a statement that says the information provided is accurate only up to a certain date.

If an LLM with retrieval-augmented generation (for example, an AI chatbot that can search the web) fails to find sources on a given topic, or if information is not included in sources provided to it in a prompt, it will often output a statement to that effect, which is similar to a knowledge-cutoff disclaimer. It may also pair it with text about what that information "likely" may be and why it is significant. This information is entirely speculative (including the very claim that it's "not documented") and may be based on loosely related topics or completely fabricated. It is also frequently combined with the tells above.

Examples

While specific information about the fauna of Studniƒçn√≠ hora is limited in the provided search results, the mountain likely supports...

Prompt refusal
Words to watch: as an AI language model, as a large language model, I'm sorry ...
Occasionally, the AI chatbot will decline to answer a prompt as written, usually with an apology and a reminder that it is "an AI language model". Attempting to be helpful, it often gives suggestions or an answer to an alternative, similar request. Outright refusals have become increasingly rare.

Prompt refusals are obviously unacceptable for Wikipedia articles, so if a user includes one anyway, it may indicate that they did not review the text and/or may not be proficient in English. Remember to assume good faith, because that editor may genuinely want to improve our coverage of knowledge gaps.

Examples

Markup
Use of Markdown
Shortcut
WP:MARKDOWN
AI chatbots are not proficient in wikitext, the markup language used to instruct Wikipedia's MediaWiki software how to format an article. As wikitext is a niche markup language, found mostly on wikis running on MediaWiki and other MediaWiki-based platforms like Miraheze, LLMs tend to lack wikitext-formatted training data. While the corpuses of chatbots did ingest millions of Wikipedia articles, these articles would not have been processed as text files containing wikitext syntax. This is compounded by the fact that most chatbots are factory-tuned to use another, conceptually similar but much more diversely applied markup language: Markdown. Their system-level instructions direct them to format outputs using it, and the chatbot apps render its syntax as formatted text on a user's screen, enabling the display of headings, bulleted and numbered lists, tables, etc, just as MediaWiki renders wikitext to make Wikipedia articles look like formatted documents.

When asked about its "formatting guidelines", a chatbot willing to reveal some of its system-level instructions will typically generate some variation of the following (this is Microsoft Copilot in mid-2025):

## Formatting Guidelines

- All output uses GitHub-flavored Markdown.  
- Use a single main title (`#`) and clear primary subheadings (`##`).  
- Keep paragraphs short (3‚Äì5 sentences, ‚â§150 words).  
- Break large topics into labeled subsections.  
- Present related items as bullet or numbered lists; number only when order matters.  
- Always leave a blank line before and after each paragraph.  
- Avoid bold or italic styling in body text unless explicitly requested.  
- Use horizontal dividers (`---`) between major sections.  
- Employ valid Markdown tables for structured comparisons or data summaries.  
- Refrain from complex Unicode symbols; stick to simple characters.  
- Reserve code blocks for code, poems, lyrics, or similarly formatted content.  
- For mathematical expressions, use LaTeX outside of code blocks.
As the above suggests, Markdown's syntax is completely different from wikitext's: Markdown uses asterisks (*) or underscores (_) instead of single-quotes (') for bold and italic formatting, hash symbols (#) instead of equals signs (=) for section headings, parentheses (()) instead of square brackets ([]) around URLs, and three symbols (---, ***, or ___) instead of four hyphens (----) for thematic breaks.

Even when they are told to do so explicitly, chatbots generally struggle to generate text using syntactically correct wikitext, as their training data lead to a drastically greater affinity for and fluency in Markdown. When told to "generate an article", a chatbot will typically default to using Markdown for the generated output, which is preserved in clipboard text by the copy functions on some chatbot platforms. If instructed to generate content for Wikipedia, the chatbot might "realize" the need to generate Wikipedia-compatible code, and might include a message like Would you like me to ... turn this into actual Wikipedia markup format (`wikitext`)?[b] in its output. If the chatbot is told to proceed, the resulting syntax will often be rudimentary, syntactically incorrect, or both. The chatbot might put its attempted-wikitext content in a Markdown-style fenced code block (its syntax for WP:PRE) surrounded by Markdown-based syntax and content, which may also be preserved by platform-specific copy-to-clipboard functions, leading to a telling footprint of both markup languages' syntax. This might include the appearance of three backticks in the text, such as: ```wikitext.[c]

The presence of faulty wikitext syntax mixed with Markdown syntax is a strong indicator that content is LLM-generated, especially if in the form of a fenced Markdown code block. However, Markdown alone is not such a strong indicator. Software developers, researchers, technical writers, and experienced internet users frequently use Markdown in tools like Obsidian and GitHub, and on platforms like Reddit, Discord, and Slack. Some writing tools and apps, such as iOS Notes, Google Docs, and Windows Notepad, support Markdown editing or exporting. The increasing ubiquity of Markdown may also lead new editors to expect or assume Wikipedia to support Markdown by default.

Citations
For non-AI-specific guidance about this, see Wikipedia:Fictitious references.
Shortcut

Broken external links
If a new article or draft has multiple citations with external links, and most of them are broken (error 404 pages), this is a strong sign of an AI-generated page, particularly if the dead links are not found in website archiving sites like Internet Archive or Archive Today. Most links become broken (see link rot) over time, but those factors make it unlikely that the link was ever valid.

Invalid DOI and ISBNs
For non-AI-specific guidance about DOI and ISBNs, see Wikipedia:DOI and Wikipedia:ISBN.
A checksum can be used to verify ISBNs. An invalid checksum is a very likely sign that an ISBN is incorrect, and citation templates will display a warning if so. Similarly, DOIs are more resistant to link rot than regular hyperlinks. Unresolvable DOIs and invalid ISBNs can be indicators of hallucinated references.

Related are DOIs that point to entirely different article and general book citations without pages. This passage, for example, was generated by ChatGPT.

Ohm's Law is a fundamental principle in the field of electrical engineering and physics that states the current passing through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the voltage across the two points, provided the temperature remains constant. Mathematically, it is expressed as V=IR, where V is the voltage, I is the current, and R is the resistance. The law was formulated by German physicist Georg Simon Ohm in 1827, and it serves as a cornerstone in the analysis and design of electrical circuits [1]. Ohm‚Äôs Law applies to many materials and components that are "ohmic," meaning their resistance remains constant regardless of the applied voltage or current. However, it does not hold for non-linear devices like diodes or transistors [2][3].

References:

1. Dorf, R. C., & Svoboda, J. A. (2010). Introduction to Electric Circuits (8th ed.). Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley & Sons. ISBN 9780470521571.

2. M. E. Van Valkenburg, ‚ÄúThe validity and limitations of Ohm‚Äôs law in non-linear circuits,‚Äù Proceedings of the IEEE, vol. 62, no. 6, pp. 769‚Äì770, Jun. 1974. doi:10.1109/PROC.1974.9547

3. C. L. Fortescue, ‚ÄúOhm‚Äôs Law in alternating current circuits,‚Äù Proceedings of the IEEE, vol. 55, no. 11, pp. 1934‚Äì1936, Nov. 1967. doi:10.1109/PROC.1967.6033

Miscellaneous
Abrupt cut offs
AI tools may abruptly stop generating content, for example if they predict the end of text sequence (appearing as <|endoftext|>) next. Also, the number of tokens that a single response has is usually limited, and further responses will require the user to select "continue generating".

This method is not foolproof, as a malformed copy/paste from one's local computer can also cause this. It may also indicate a copyright violation rather than the use of an LLM.

Discrepancies in writing style and variety of English
A sudden shift in an editor's writing style, such as unexpectedly flawless grammar compared to their other communication, may indicate the use of AI tools.

Another discrepancy is a mismatch of user location, national ties of the topic to a variety of English, and the variety of English used. A human writer from India writing about an Indian university would probably not use American English; however, LLM outputs use American English by default, unless prompted otherwise.[4] Note that non-native English speakers tend to mix up English varieties, and such signs should only raise suspicion if there is a sudden and complete shift in an editor's English variety use.

Age of text relative to ChatGPT launch
ChatGPT was launched to the public on November 30, 2022. Although OpenAI had similarly powerful LLMs before then, they were paid services and not particularly accessible or known to lay people. ChatGPT experienced extreme growth immediately on launch.

It is very unlikely that any particular text added to Wikipedia prior to November 30, 2022 was generated by an LLM. If an edit to a page was made before this date, AI use can be safely ruled out for that revision. While some text added as far back as 20 years ago may appear to match some of the AI signs given in this list, and even convincingly appear to have been AI generated, the vastness of Wikipedia allows for these rare coincidences.

Overwhelmingly verbose edit summaries
AI-generated edit summaries are often unusually long, written as formal, first-person paragraphs without abbreviations, and/or conspicuously itemize Wikipedia's conventions.

Most editors using AI do not ask for summaries to be generated.

Ineffective indicators
False accusations of AI use can drive away new editors and foster an atmosphere of suspicion. Before claiming AI was used, consider if Dunning‚ÄìKruger effect and confirmation bias is clouding your judgement. In particular, there are several somewhat commonly used indicators which are ineffective (and may even indicate the opposite) in LLM detection.

Perfect grammar: While modern LLMs are known for their high grammatical proficiency, many editors are also skilled writers or come from professional writing backgrounds. (See also ¬ß Discrepancies in writing style and variety of English.)
"Bland" or "robotic" prose: By default, modern LLMs tend toward effusive and verbose prose, as detailed above; while this tendency is formulaic, it may not scan as "robotic" to those unfamiliar with AI writing.[6]
Bizarre wikitext: While LLMs may hallucinate templates or generate wikitext code with invalid syntax for reasons explained in ¬ß Use of Markdown, they are not likely to generate content with certain random-seeming, "inexplicable" errors and artifacts (excluding the ones listed on this page in ¬ß Markup). Bizarrely placed HTML tags like <span> are more indicative of poorly programmed browser extensions or a known bug with Wikipedia's content translation tool (T113137). Misplaced syntax like ''Catch-22 i''s a satirical novel. (rendered as "Catch-22 is a satirical novel.") are more indicative of mistakes in VisualEditor, where such errors are harder to notice than in source editing.
